CFLIT: Coexisting Federated Learning and Information Transfer

Zehong Lin, , Hang Liu, , and Ying-Jun Angela Zhang Zehong Lin was with the Department of Information Engineering, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong. He is now with the Department of Electronic and Computer Engineering, The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, Hong Kong (e-mail: eezhlin@ust.hk). Hang Liu was with the Department of Information Engineering, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong. He is now with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Cornell Tech, Cornell University, New York, NY 10044 USA (e-mail: hl2382@cornell.edu). Ying-Jun Angela Zhang is with the Department of Information Engineering, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong (e-mail: yjzhang@ie.cuhk.edu.hk).
Abstract

Future wireless networks are expected to support diverse mobile services, including artificial intelligence (AI) services and ubiquitous data transmissions. Federated learning (FL), as a revolutionary learning approach, enables collaborative AI model training across distributed mobile edge devices. By exploiting the superposition property of multiple-access channels, over-the-air computation allows concurrent model uploading from massive devices over the same radio resources, and thus significantly reduces the communication cost of FL. In this paper, we study the coexistence of over-the-air FL and traditional information transfer (IT) in a mobile edge network, where an access point (AP) coordinates a set of devices for over-the-air FL and serves multiple devices for information transfer in the meantime. We propose a coexisting federated learning and information transfer (CFLIT) communication framework, where the FL and IT devices share the wireless spectrum in an orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM) system. Under this framework, we aim to maximize the IT data rate and guarantee a given FL convergence performance by optimizing the long-term radio resource allocation. A key challenge that limits the spectrum efficiency of the coexisting system lies in the large overhead incurred by frequent communication between the server and edge devices for FL model aggregation. To address the challenge, we rigorously analyze the impact of the computation-to-communication ratio on the convergence of over-the-air FL in wireless fading channels. The analysis reveals the existence of an optimal computation-to-communication ratio that minimizes the amount of radio resources needed for over-the-air FL to converge to a given error tolerance. Based on the analysis, we propose a low-complexity online algorithm to jointly optimize the radio resource allocation for both the FL devices and IT devices. We further derive an analytical expression of the achievable data rate of IT users. Extensive numerical simulations verify the superior performance of the proposed design for the coexistence of FL and IT devices in wireless cellular systems.

Index Terms:
Edge intelligence, federated learning (FL), over-the-air computation, coexistence, orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing (OFDM), multiple access.

I Introduction

The proliferation of mobile artificial intelligence (AI) services, such as autonomous driving and intelligent personal assistants, triggers the emergence of a new paradigm called edge intelligence [1, 2, 3], which migrates the training and inference processes of AI models from central cloud servers to the edge of wireless networks, i.e., edge servers and mobile devices. Federated learning (FL) [4] has been widely perceived as a promising edge learning framework that allows mobile devices to collaboratively train a shared AI model without disclosing the raw data. Specifically, mobile devices download the global model from an edge server for local model training and upload the updated local models to the edge server. The server then updates the global model by aggregating a linear combination of local models. To relieve the communication burden of FL model uploading and aggregation, over-the-air computation [5] has been introduced into the FL model aggregation process [6]. By exploiting the superposition property of multiple-access channels, over-the-air model aggregation allows massive devices to simultaneously transmit their local models using the same channel and coherently aligns the local models at the server. The required bandwidth and communication latency for over-the-air computation are independent of the number of devices, thus significantly reducing the communication cost for FL model aggregation.

Extensive studies have been conducted to design over-the-air FL systems in wireless networks [7, 6, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13]. Most prior work, however, considers over-the-air computation over narrow-band systems and is not applicable to modern broadband wireless networks. To facilitate broadband implementation, the recent work in [14] proposed a broadband over-the-air model aggregation approach in orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM) systems. Nonetheless, Ref. [14] ignored the coexistence of over-the-air FL with traditional information transfer (IT) services. Note that future wireless networks are required to support multiple devices with different data communication demands at the same time [15, 16, 17]. For instance, FL devices need to frequently communicate model information with an access point (AP), which in the meanwhile serves another set of devices for data streaming. Therefore, it is of great importance to design a coexisting system to support the coexistence of over-the-air FL and IT in wireless networks. This motivates the work in this paper.

Designing the above coexisting system is a challenging task. Although over-the-air model aggregation greatly reduces the bandwidth cost compared with traditional FL, uploading high-dimensional model parameters to the edge server iteratively until model convergence still leads to an extremely high bandwidth cost. Such a high bandwidth consumption leaves very little spectrum for IT devices to transmit their data traffic. Therefore, minimizing the bandwidth consumption of over-the-air FL is a critical problem in the design of the coexisting system. Note that the total bandwidth consumption is sensitive to the total number of communication rounds, which is critically determined by the design of the over-the-air FL training process. Consequently, we shall carefully study the FL mechanism design to minimize the bandwidth consumption needed for convergence.

There are two main research directions towards minimizing the bandwidth consumption of FL in the literature: one is to reduce the communication bandwidth cost per communication round and the other is to reduce the total number of communication rounds for model update. On one hand, the communication cost in each round can be reduced by model compression [18]. Existing approaches for model compression are divided into two categories: quantization [19] and sparsification [20]. In the former, local models are quantized into finite-bit digits to reduce the amount of data in model uploading [21, 22]. In the latter, local gradients are transformed to low-dimensional vectors at the transmitters by exploiting the gradient sparsity and recovered at the server by compressed sensing [23, 24, 25]. On the other hand, the total number of communication rounds can be reduced by carefully selecting the computation-to-communication ratio. For example, [4, 26, 27] have reported that the number of model updates computed locally before uploading the local model parameters to the server for model aggregation critically determines the total number of communication rounds needed for convergence. Specifically, a smaller number of local updates (i.e., a lower computation-to-communication ratio) means more frequent model aggregation, and thus a higher communication cost. Meanwhile, a larger number of local updates (i.e., a higher computation-to-communication ratio) leads to infrequent model aggregation, which inevitably slows down the learning convergence especially when the data distribution across devices is heterogeneous. Inspired by this observation, the authors in [28] optimized the number of local updates to minimize the required number of FL communication rounds. Moreover, Refs. [29, 30] extended the result in [28] by taking the wireless network characteristics into account.

Although the current work in [23, 24, 25] has demonstrated the effectiveness of model compression on reducing the communication cost for over-the-air model aggregation, the number of model parameters after compression is still very large. For instance, the famous deep learning model AlexNet in [31] consists of more than 60 million parameters. Even the state-of-the-art gradient sparsification approach has compressed the transmitted local gradients with compression ratio of 10%percent1010\% [25], transmitting the sparsified model to the server still consumes a large amount of radio resources in each round. In light of this, reducing the required number of model communication rounds is critical to save the bandwidth cost. The prior work on the optimization of computation-to-communication ratio [28, 29, 30], however, considers conventional orthogonal transmission and is not applicable to over-the-air FL. For over-the-air FL, the wireless channel fading inevitably induces signal misalignment in model aggregation, which brings a considerable error in the aggregated global gradient. Such an error is coupled with the effect of local model updating during the training process and slows down the learning convergence rate [8]. Therefore, it is necessary to investigate the coupled impact of the model aggregation error and the number of local updates on the bandwidth consumption needed for the convergence of over-the-air FL. Nonetheless, this important study is largely overlooked in the literature.

In this paper, we study a coexisting federated learning and information transfer (CFLIT) system in a single-cell mobile edge network consisting of a single AP, a set of FL devices, and a set of IT devices. The AP coordinates the FL devices for over-the-air FL and simultaneously serves the IT devices for uplink IT using the same uplink spectrum. To minimize the bandwidth cost for FL, we first analyze the convergence behavior of over-the-air FL as a function of local model updates and the total number of communication rounds in a wireless fading channel. Based on the analysis, we optimize the key parameters, i.e., the number of local updates and the number of FL communication rounds, to minimize the radio resources needed for over-the-air model aggregation. Then, we formulate a radio resource allocation problem to simultaneously maximize the average IT data rate and guarantee the convergence of over-the-air FL in a given time horizon. The lack of non-causal information of future channel state makes it difficult to jointly optimize the long-term radio resource allocation for both the FL and IT devices with an offline scheme. To overcome this difficulty, we propose a low-complexity online algorithm to make real-time allocation decisions based on the current observation of channel state information (CSI). To the best of our knowledge, this is the first paper that studies the joint communication and learning design in a wireless network to support the coexistence of over-the-air FL and IT. The main contributions of this paper are summarized as follows.

  • •

    Bandwidth cost minimization for over-the-air FL: We theoretically analyze the achievable training loss of over-the-air FL under mild assumptions to characterize the impact of the computation-to-communication ratio on the over-the-air FL convergence. We then derive a closed-form expression of the optimal computation-to-communication ratio that yields the minimum number of communication rounds. The analysis provides a useful guideline on how to optimize the key parameters of FL for minimizing the bandwidth cost for over-the-air model aggregation.

  • •

    CFLIT communication framework: We develop a novel CFLIT communication framework to coordinate both over-the-air model aggregation and uplink data streaming. Specifically, the FL devices and the IT devices simultaneously transmit local model updates and general data streams, respectively, to the AP over time-varying broadband channels. We formulate a CFLIT radio resource allocation problem to maximize the average IT data rate and at the same time ensure FL convergence in a given duration. To minimize the radio resource consumption for FL convergence guarantee, the transceiver design and learning parameters are jointly taken into account.

  • •

    Low-complexity online algorithm for radio resource allocation: We propose an efficient threshold-based online subcarrier allocation algorithm for CFLIT by mimicking the offline optimal solution. Unlike the offline scheme, the proposed algorithm does not require the non-causal CSI of the entire time horizon. Instead, it relies on the instantaneous channel gains of IT devices in the current symbol duration only and allocates subcarriers based on an optimized threshold. Moreover, we provide theoretical performance analysis to prove the rate improvement of the proposed online algorithm.

Simulation results verify our theoretical analysis and show that the proposed online algorithm performs very close to the offline optimal solution. Moreover, the proposed design achieves a better FL performance and a higher average IT data rate compared with the baseline approaches.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In Section II, we describe the CFLIT system model and the problem formulation. In Section III, we present the convergence analysis for over-the-air FL. Based on this, we derive analytical expressions to optimize the number of local updates and the number of communication rounds. In Section IV, we propose an efficient online algorithm to optimize the subcarrier allocation and provide theoretical performance analysis. In Section V, we evaluate the proposed design via extensive simulations. Finally, we conclude the paper in Section VI.

II System Model and Problem Formulation

II-A CFLIT System Model

We consider a single-cell CFLIT system, where K𝐾K FL devices, indexed by 𝒦={1,⋯,K}𝒦1⋯𝐾\mathcal{K}=\{1,\cdots,K\}, collaboratively train an AI model by exchanging model information with an AP. At the same time, N𝑁N IT devices, indexed by 𝒩={1,⋯,N}𝒩1⋯𝑁\mathcal{N}=\{1,\cdots,N\}, transmit information-bearing signals to the AP through the uplink channels. All the nodes are equipped with single antenna. As shown in [32], the uplink model uploading and aggregation incur a high bandwidth cost and act as the communication bottleneck of FL. To significantly reduce the communication cost for FL, we adopt the over-the-air computation technique to accelerate the uplink model aggregation.111Over-the-air computation requires synchronization of the transmitters. For simplicity, we assume in this paper that the local model information transmitted from the FL devices is perfectly synchronized, which can be achieved by the state-of-the-art synchronization mechanism; see, e.g., [33]. We refer to [33] for more technical details on over-the-air signal synchronization. By employing OFDM modulation, the total uplink bandwidth is divided into M𝑀M orthogonal OFDM subcarriers, indexed by ℳ={1,⋯,M}ℳ1⋯𝑀\mathcal{M}=\{1,\cdots,M\}. The AP is in charge of allocating subcarriers to support the over-the-air model aggregation of the FL devices and the data transmissions from the IT devices. We consider a time horizon consisting of S𝑆S OFDM symbols, where S𝑆S represents the allowed time for accomplishing the FL task and is determined by the specific application. The total number of available OFDM resource blocks (RBs) for accomplishing over-the-air FL and IT is M​S𝑀𝑆MS. To avoid large inter-user interference, each subcarrier is allocated to either over-the-air model aggregation or at most one IT device.

We assume a block fading channel model, where the channel coefficients between the devices and the AP evolve independently over each coherence block following the independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.) Gaussian distribution of 𝒞​𝒩​(0,1)𝒞𝒩01\mathcal{CN}(0,1). Suppose that the considered time interval of S𝑆S OFDM symbols is much larger than the coherence block length. We need to consider long-term dynamic RB allocation over multiple blocks with varying channel coefficients. We consider a training-based channel estimation protocol where a number of time slots at the beginning of each coherence block is used to transmit pilots for uplink channel estimation. We ignore the overhead and error in channel estimation222We note that the channel estimation overhead and error have a negative impact on system performance. The overhead of channel estimation reduces the available number of RBs, while the estimation error potentially leads to inaccurate RB allocation, making the solution sub-optimal. To mitigate these effects, an efficient channel estimation scheme is needed, which, however, is beyond the scope of this paper. and assume that only the CSI of the current coherence block is available.

The workflow of the transmitters and the receiver in the CFLIT system is shown in Fig. 1. On one hand, the data stream of each IT device is first segmented into parallel streams, which are then modulated into digital signals on the allocated subcarriers before being transmitted to the AP. On the other hand, to leverage over-the-air computation for model aggregation, the local model symbols of FL devices are modulated into analog signals. We employ analog amplitude modulation [14] for the modulation, where each symbol is converted to a uniform waveform, e.g., a square wave, with amplitude proportional to the value of the original symbol. Due to the superposition nature of multiple-access channels, the received signal is approximately a square wave with amplitude proportional to the weighted sum of local symbols. Therefore, model aggregation can be efficiently achieved by transmitter-side pre-equalization. The receiver of the AP performs digital demodulation on the subcarriers allocated to IT and analog amplitude demodulation on the other subcarriers. As a result, the AP is able to extract data streams and over-the-air aggregated model symbols from the subcarriers accordingly.

Define om,ssubscript𝑜𝑚𝑠o_{m,s} as the binary subcarrier allocation indicator for over-the-air FL on the m𝑚m-th subcarrier of the s𝑠s-th OFDM symbol. We have om,s=1subscript𝑜𝑚𝑠1o_{m,s}=1 if the m𝑚m-th subcarrier of the s𝑠s-th OFDM symbol is allocated to over-the-air model aggregation and om,s=0subscript𝑜𝑚𝑠0o_{m,s}=0 otherwise. Moreover, we define bn,m,ssubscript𝑏𝑛𝑚𝑠b_{n,m,s} as the binary subcarrier allocation indicator for IT devices on the m𝑚m-th subcarrier of the s𝑠s-th OFDM symbol. That is, bn,m,s=1subscript𝑏𝑛𝑚𝑠1b_{n,m,s}=1 if the m𝑚m-th subcarrier of the s𝑠s-th OFDM symbol is allocated to IT device n𝑛n and bn,m,s=0subscript𝑏𝑛𝑚𝑠0b_{n,m,s}=0 otherwise. Consequently, we have ∑n=1Nbn,m,s+om,s≤1superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝑏𝑛𝑚𝑠subscript𝑜𝑚𝑠1\sum_{n=1}^{N}b_{n,m,s}+o_{m,s}\leq 1 for all m,s𝑚𝑠m,s. In the following, we describe the over-the-air FL and IT models in detail.

In this paper, we assume perfect downlink model broadcasting following [10, 11, 12, 13, 24, 34] and focus on the uplink communication design for over-the-air model aggregation, which is elaborated as follows.

With over-the-air model aggregation, we need d𝑑d RBs in each communication round to upload the d𝑑d-dimensional vectors {𝚫k,t}subscript𝚫𝑘𝑡\{\bm{\Delta}_{k,t}\} as each entry occupies one RB. Consequently, over-the-air FL requires d​T𝑑𝑇dT RBs in total to complete T𝑇T rounds of model aggregation.333Model compression by, e.g., gradient sparsification [23, 24, 25], can further reduce the dimensionality of local model changes. Note that our design is readily applicable to any over-the-air FL design that applies gradient sparsification by replacing the model change vectors with the sparsified gradient vectors. Accordingly, the total number of RBs for over-the-air model aggregation is reduced from d​T𝑑𝑇dT to d′​Tsuperscript𝑑′𝑇d^{\prime}T, where d′<dsuperscript𝑑′𝑑d^{\prime}<d represents the dimension of compressed local gradient vectors. We define 𝚽≜{(m,s):om,s=1,∀m∈ℳ,s∈𝒮}≜𝚽conditional-set𝑚𝑠formulae-sequencesubscript𝑜𝑚𝑠1formulae-sequencefor-all𝑚ℳ𝑠𝒮\mathbf{\Phi}\triangleq\{(m,s):o_{m,s}=1,\forall m\in\mathcal{M},s\in\mathcal{S}\} as the set of indices of all the subcarriers allocated to over-the-air FL, where |𝚽|=d​T𝚽𝑑𝑇|\mathbf{\Phi}|=dT. We partition 𝚽𝚽\mathbf{\Phi} into T𝑇T disjoint d𝑑d-dimensional vectors, where the t𝑡t-th vector 𝚽tsubscript𝚽𝑡\mathbf{\Phi}_{t} denotes the RB indices assigned to the t𝑡t-th model aggregation round. For example, the first d𝑑d RBs in 𝚽𝚽\mathbf{\Phi} is grouped as 𝚽1subscript𝚽1\mathbf{\Phi}_{1}. We denote the entries of 𝚽tsubscript𝚽𝑡\mathbf{\Phi}_{t} by 𝚽t≜[Φ​[d​t+1],⋯,Φ​[d​(t+1)]]T≜subscript𝚽𝑡superscriptΦdelimited-[]𝑑𝑡1⋯Φdelimited-[]𝑑𝑡1𝑇\mathbf{\Phi}_{t}\triangleq[\Phi[dt+1],\cdots,\Phi[d(t+1)]]^{T}.

II-C IT Model

As over-the-air FL requires d​T𝑑𝑇dT RBs in total, the remaining M​S−d​T𝑀𝑆𝑑𝑇MS-dT RBs are assigned to IT devices for uplink data transmissions, where each RB is allocated to one IT device. Let gn,m,s∈ℂsubscript𝑔𝑛𝑚𝑠ℂg_{n,m,s}\in\mathbb{C} denote the channel coefficient between IT device n𝑛n and the AP on the m𝑚m-th subcarrier of the s𝑠s-th OFDM symbol. Then, the corresponding received signal on the m𝑚m-th subcarrier of the s𝑠s-th OFDM symbol can be expressed as

ym,s=∑n=1Nbn,m,s​gn,m,s​P2​xn,m,s+zm,s,subscript𝑦𝑚𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝑏𝑛𝑚𝑠subscript𝑔𝑛𝑚𝑠subscript𝑃2subscript𝑥𝑛𝑚𝑠subscript𝑧𝑚𝑠y_{m,s}=\sum_{n=1}^{N}b_{n,m,s}g_{n,m,s}\sqrt{P_{2}}x_{n,m,s}+z_{m,s}, (11)

where xn,m,ssubscript𝑥𝑛𝑚𝑠x_{n,m,s} is the digitally-modulated transmit signal with 𝔼​[|xn,m,s|2]=1𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑛𝑚𝑠21\mathbb{E}[|x_{n,m,s}|^{2}]=1, P2subscript𝑃2P_{2} is the transmit power of each IT device, and zm,s∼𝒞​𝒩​(0,σ2)similar-tosubscript𝑧𝑚𝑠𝒞𝒩0superscript𝜎2z_{m,s}\sim\mathcal{CN}(0,\sigma^{2}) is the AWGN. Rn,m,s=bn,m,s​log2⁡(1+P2​|gn,m,s|2ϕ​σ2),subscript𝑅𝑛𝑚𝑠subscript𝑏𝑛𝑚𝑠subscript21subscript𝑃2superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑛𝑚𝑠2italic-ϕsuperscript𝜎2R_{n,m,s}=b_{n,m,s}\log_{2}\left(1+\frac{P_{2}|g_{n,m,s}|^{2}}{\phi\sigma^{2}}\right), (12)

where ϕ≥1italic-ϕ1\phi\geq 1 is the achievable rate gap due to channel coding and modulation. Consequently, the average IT sum-rate on each OFDM RB is given by

II-D Problem Formulation

We consider the joint optimization of radio resource allocation and the hyper-parameters of FL, including the number of communication rounds T𝑇T and the number of local updates τ𝜏\tau. To facilitate the problem formulation, we first introduce the definition of an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-accurate solution to characterize the ultimate target of FL model training.

Definition 1 (ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-accurate solution). The output of the FL training process 𝐰^Tsubscript^𝐰𝑇\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{T} is an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-accurate solution to the FL loss minimization problem min𝐰⁡F​(𝐰)subscript𝐰𝐹𝐰\min_{\mathbf{w}}F(\mathbf{w}) if

F​(𝐰^T)−F∗≤ϵ,𝐹subscript^𝐰𝑇superscript𝐹italic-ϵF(\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{T})-F^{*}\leq\epsilon, (14)

where F∗≜F​(𝐰∗)≜superscript𝐹𝐹superscript𝐰F^{*}\!\triangleq\!F(\mathbf{w}^{*}\!), 𝐰∗superscript𝐰\mathbf{w}^{*} is the global optimum of F​(⋅)𝐹⋅F(\cdot), and ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon\!>\!0 is a given positive small number.

The value of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon in (14) measures the tolerance of FL model training. A smaller ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon leads to a smaller optimality gap and thus a better training performance. We note that the training performance F​(𝐰^T)𝐹subscript^𝐰𝑇F(\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{T}) is determined by the model aggregation quality as well as the learning design, including the choices of the communication rounds T𝑇T and the number of local updates τ𝜏\tau. In particular, as discussed in the Introduction, the value of τ𝜏\tau determines the computation-to-communication ratio and critically impacts T𝑇T to achieve a certain training performance. Furthermore, a larger T𝑇T implies more RBs needed for over-the-air FL training, leaving fewer RBs for data transmissions of IT devices.

Besides the learning hyper-parameters τ𝜏\tau and T𝑇T, the FL training performance and the IT data rate are both affected by the wireless channel fading and thus depend on the subcarrier allocation decisions. On one hand, wireless channel fading affects the channel gains and thus the data rate of the IT process as given in (II-C). On the other hand, the transceiver design variables {pk,Φt​[i],ct​[i]}subscript𝑝𝑘subscriptΦ𝑡delimited-[]𝑖subscript𝑐𝑡delimited-[]𝑖\{p_{k,\Phi_{t}[i]},c_{t}[i]\} of over-the-air FL jointly affect the quality of the model aggregation and the resulting global model update. However, we emphasize that FL and IT have different sensitivities against communication errors. The gradient descent step in FL is naturally robust against a small gradient error as slightly perturbing the descent direction does not affect the convergence to the local minimum; see [35, Fig. 5]. To better utilize the radio resources to support the coexistence of FL and IT, we exploit the different error sensitivities of FL and IT and allocate the subcarriers to IT if the IT devices have good channel conditions. The remaining radio resources are then utilized for FL model aggregation. To this end, we propose to maximize the IT data rate and at the same time constrain the expected output of the FL training process to be ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-accurate in S𝑆S symbol durations. Note that the FL subcarrier allocation affects the FL communication rounds T𝑇T, and hence is coupled with the IT subcarrier allocation. By taking the communication variables {bn,m,s,om,s,pk,Φt​[i],ct​[i]}subscript𝑏𝑛𝑚𝑠subscript𝑜𝑚𝑠subscript𝑝𝑘subscriptΦ𝑡delimited-[]𝑖subscript𝑐𝑡delimited-[]𝑖\{b_{n,m,s},o_{m,s},p_{k,\Phi_{t}[i]},c_{t}[i]\} and the learning hyper-parameters {T,τ}𝑇𝜏\{T,\tau\} into account, we formulate the CFLIT system optimization problem as:

(P1):​max{bn,m,s,om,s,T,τ}{pk,Φt​[i],ct​[i]}(P1):subscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘subscriptΦ𝑡delimited-[]𝑖subscript𝑐𝑡delimited-[]𝑖subscript𝑏𝑛𝑚𝑠subscript𝑜𝑚𝑠𝑇𝜏\displaystyle\text{(P1):}\ \max_{\underset{\{p_{k,\Phi_{t}[i]},c_{t}[i]\}}{\{b_{n,m,s},o_{m,s},T,\tau\}}}~{} Ravgsubscript𝑅avg\displaystyle R_{\text{avg}} (15a)
s.t.formulae-sequencest\displaystyle{\rm s.t.}~{}~{}~{} 𝔼​[F​(𝐰^T;τ)−F∗]≤ϵ,𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript^𝐰𝑇𝜏superscript𝐹italic-ϵ\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[F(\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{T};\tau)-F^{*}\right]\leq\epsilon, (15b)
∑s=1S∑m=1Mom,s≥d​T,superscriptsubscript𝑠1𝑆superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝑜𝑚𝑠𝑑𝑇\displaystyle\sum_{s=1}^{S}\sum_{m=1}^{M}o_{m,s}\geq dT, (15c)
∑n=1Nbn,m,s+om,s≤1,∀m,s,superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝑏𝑛𝑚𝑠subscript𝑜𝑚𝑠1for-all𝑚𝑠\displaystyle\sum_{n=1}^{N}b_{n,m,s}+o_{m,s}\leq 1,\forall m,s, (15d)
bn,m,s∈{0,1},∀n,m,s,subscript𝑏𝑛𝑚𝑠01for-all𝑛𝑚𝑠\displaystyle b_{n,m,s}\in\{0,1\},\forall n,m,s, (15e)
om,s∈{0,1},∀m,s,subscript𝑜𝑚𝑠01for-all𝑚𝑠\displaystyle o_{m,s}\in\{0,1\},\forall m,s, (15f)
|pk,Φt​[i]|2≤P1,∀k∈𝒦,Φt​[i],formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘subscriptΦ𝑡delimited-[]𝑖2subscript𝑃1for-all𝑘𝒦subscriptΦ𝑡delimited-[]𝑖\displaystyle|p_{k,\Phi_{t}[i]}|^{2}\leq P_{1},\forall k\in\mathcal{K},\Phi_{t}[i], (15g)
T,τ∈ℤ+,𝑇𝜏superscriptℤ\displaystyle T,\tau\in\mathbb{Z}^{+}, (15h)

where the expectation is taken with respect to the local mini-batch samples, the communication noise, and the channel fading coefficients. F​(𝐰^T;τ)𝐹subscript^𝐰𝑇𝜏F(\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{T};\tau) is the achieved training loss after T𝑇T FL communication rounds with the number of local updates given by τ𝜏\tau. In Problem (P1), the constraint (15b) guarantees an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-accurate solution of FL training, (15c) ensures a sufficient number of allocated RBs for over-the-air FL, (15d) implies that each OFDM RB is assigned to either the over-the-air model aggregation or at most one IT data stream, and (15g) represents the transmit power constraints at FL devices.

The difficulty of solving Problem (P1) is twofold. First, to satisfy the FL convergence requirement in (15b), we must understand how the learning hyper-parameters (T,τ)𝑇𝜏(T,\tau), the transceiver design variables {pk,Φt​[i],ct​[i]}subscript𝑝𝑘subscriptΦ𝑡delimited-[]𝑖subscript𝑐𝑡delimited-[]𝑖\{p_{k,\Phi_{t}[i]},c_{t}[i]\}, and the subcarrier allocation decisions {om,s}subscript𝑜𝑚𝑠\{o_{m,s}\} jointly affect the achieved training loss F​(𝐰^T;τ)𝐹subscript^𝐰𝑇𝜏F(\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{T};\tau) of over-the-air FL. However, there does not exist an explicit analytical expression to characterize the above coupled impact in the existing literature. This makes it difficult to quantify the required number of RBs for over-the-air model aggregation in advance and minimize it accordingly to optimize the IT performance. Second, to solve (P1) optimally, we need to know the CSI for the entire horizon s=1,⋯,S𝑠1⋯𝑆s=1,\cdots,S at the beginning of time. In practice, however, such non-causal CSI is not available. That is, we need to optimize {bn,m,s,om,s}subscript𝑏𝑛𝑚𝑠subscript𝑜𝑚𝑠\{b_{n,m,s},o_{m,s}\} for each symbol duration s𝑠s based on the instantaneous CSI that is observed at that time. Therefore, an online RB allocation scheme that only depends on the current channel coefficients is required. In the next section, we analyze the performance of over-the-air FL with an arbitrary choice of (T,τ)𝑇𝜏(T,\tau) under mild assumptions on the learning model. To minimize the radio resource consumption of over-the-air FL, we optimize the transceiver design variables {pk,Φt​[i],ct​[i]}subscript𝑝𝑘subscriptΦ𝑡delimited-[]𝑖subscript𝑐𝑡delimited-[]𝑖\{p_{k,\Phi_{t}[i]},c_{t}[i]\} and use the analytical result to compute the optimal solution of (T,τ)𝑇𝜏(T,\tau) to (P1) in the asymptotic regime. Then, in Section IV, we propose a low-complexity online algorithm for subcarrier allocation and analyze its performance.

III Convergence Analysis and Learning Optimization

In this section, we analyze the convergence of over-the-air FL. To facilitate the analysis, we first present the assumptions on the local loss functions and analyze the model aggregation error in over-the-air model aggregation. Based on this, we show a sufficient condition for FL convergence and derive an asymptotic upper bound of the learning performance in terms of 𝔼​[F​(𝐰^T)−F∗]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript^𝐰𝑇superscript𝐹\mathbb{E}[F(\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{T})-F^{*}]. Finally, we use the derived bound to optimize the learning hyper-parameters τ𝜏\tau and T𝑇T.

III-A Assumptions and Preliminaries

We make the following assumptions on the local loss functions F1,⋯,FKsubscript𝐹1⋯subscript𝐹𝐾F_{1},\cdots,F_{K}:

Assumption 1: F1,⋯,FKsubscript𝐹1⋯subscript𝐹𝐾F_{1},\cdots,F_{K} are all μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex, i.e., ∀𝐰,𝐰′∈ℝd×1,for-all𝐰superscript𝐰′superscriptℝ𝑑1\forall\mathbf{w},\mathbf{w}^{\prime}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times 1},

Fk​(𝐰)≥Fk​(𝐰′)+(𝐰−𝐰′)T​∇Fk​(𝐰′)+μ2​‖𝐰−𝐰′‖22.subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝐰′superscript𝐰superscript𝐰′𝑇∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝐰′𝜇2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝐰superscript𝐰′22F_{k}(\mathbf{w})\geq F_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{\prime})+(\mathbf{w}-\mathbf{w}^{\prime})^{T}\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{\prime})+\frac{\mu}{2}\|\mathbf{w}-\mathbf{w}^{\prime}\|_{2}^{2}. (16)

Assumption 2: F1,⋯,FKsubscript𝐹1⋯subscript𝐹𝐾F_{1},\cdots,F_{K} are all L𝐿L-smooth, i.e., ∀𝐰for-all𝐰\forall\mathbf{w}, 𝐰′∈ℝd×1,superscript𝐰′superscriptℝ𝑑1\mathbf{w}^{\prime}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times 1},

Fk​(𝐰)≤Fk​(𝐰′)+(𝐰−𝐰′)T​∇Fk​(𝐰′)+L2​‖𝐰−𝐰′‖22.subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝐰′superscript𝐰superscript𝐰′𝑇∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝐰′𝐿2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝐰superscript𝐰′22F_{k}(\mathbf{w})\leq F_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{\prime})+(\mathbf{w}-\mathbf{w}^{\prime})^{T}\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{\prime})+\frac{L}{2}\|\mathbf{w}-\mathbf{w}^{\prime}\|_{2}^{2}. (17)

Assumption 3: The expected l2subscript𝑙2l_{2}-norm of the stochastic gradient ∇Fk​(𝐰k,tl,ξk,tl)∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑡𝑙superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘𝑡𝑙\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{k,t}^{l},\xi_{k,t}^{l}) is upper bounded, i.e., ∀k,t,l,for-all𝑘𝑡𝑙\forall k,t,l,

𝔼​[‖∇Fk​(𝐰k,tl,ξk,tl)‖22]≤G2,𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑡𝑙superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘𝑡𝑙22superscript𝐺2\mathbb{E}[\|\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{k,t}^{l},\xi_{k,t}^{l})\|_{2}^{2}]\leq G^{2}, (18)

where the expectation is taken with respect to the local mini-batch samples, the communication noise, and the channel fading coefficients.

Remark III.1

The above assumptions are commonly adopted in the literature; see, e.g., [26, 28, 30]. In practice, Assumption 3 can be guaranteed by imposing an additional gradient clipping operation [36].

The following definition defines a metric of data heterogeneity.

Definition 2 (ΓΓ\Gamma-data heterogeneity). The degree of data heterogeneity across the FL devices is quantified by

Γ≜F∗−∑k=1Kρk​Fk∗,≜Γsuperscript𝐹superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝜌𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑘\Gamma\triangleq F^{*}-\sum_{k=1}^{K}\rho_{k}F_{k}^{*}, (19)

where Fk∗superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑘F_{k}^{*} denotes the minimum value of local loss function Fk​(⋅)subscript𝐹𝑘⋅F_{k}(\cdot) at FL device k𝑘k, and Γ≥0Γ0\Gamma\geq 0.

As the number of local training samples goes to infinity, i.e., Dk→∞,∀k∈𝒦formulae-sequence→subscript𝐷𝑘for-all𝑘𝒦D_{k}\rightarrow\infty,\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, the locally trained models converge to the global model when the training data are i.i.d. distributed, i.e., 𝐰k∗→𝐰∗,∀k∈𝒦formulae-sequence→superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘superscript𝐰for-all𝑘𝒦\mathbf{w}_{k}^{*}\rightarrow\mathbf{w}^{*},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, and thus Γ→0→Γ0\Gamma\rightarrow 0. For non-i.i.d. data distribution, Γ≠0Γ0\Gamma\neq 0. The larger ΓΓ\Gamma, the more heterogeneous the data distribution is.

As shown in Section II-B, over-the-air model aggregation constructs a noisy estimate 𝐫^tsubscript^𝐫𝑡\hat{\mathbf{r}}_{t} at the AP using (II-B). The estimation accuracy of 𝐫^tsubscript^𝐫𝑡\hat{\mathbf{r}}_{t} affects the convergence of over-the-air FL because the estimation error leads to inaccurate global model update. We quantify the estimation accuracy by the MSE between 𝐫^tsubscript^𝐫𝑡\hat{\mathbf{r}}_{t} and the ground-truth 𝐫tsubscript𝐫𝑡\mathbf{r}_{t} as

et=𝔼​[‖𝐫^t−𝐫t‖22],subscript𝑒𝑡𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript^𝐫𝑡subscript𝐫𝑡22e_{t}=\mathbb{E}[\|\hat{\mathbf{r}}_{t}-\mathbf{r}_{t}\|_{2}^{2}], (20)

where the expectation is taken with respect to the communication noise.

It is shown in [8] that a larger model aggregation error etsubscript𝑒𝑡e_{t} leads to a smaller convergence rate of over-the-air FL. Therefore, we can optimize the transceiver design variables {pk,Φt​[i],ct​[i]}subscript𝑝𝑘subscriptΦ𝑡delimited-[]𝑖subscript𝑐𝑡delimited-[]𝑖\{p_{k,\Phi_{t}[i]},c_{t}[i]\} by minimizing etsubscript𝑒𝑡e_{t}, as detailed by the following lemma.

Lemma III.1

Given the channel coefficients {hk,Φt​[i]}subscriptℎ𝑘subscriptΦ𝑡delimited-[]𝑖\{h_{k,\Phi_{t}[i]}\}, the optimal pk,Φt​[i]subscript𝑝𝑘subscriptΦ𝑡delimited-[]𝑖p_{k,\Phi_{t}[i]} and ct​[i]subscript𝑐𝑡delimited-[]𝑖c_{t}[i] are

pk,Φt​[i]=ρk​νk,tct​[i]​hk,Φt​[i],∀k∈𝒦,ct​[i]=1P1​maxk∈𝒦⁡ρk​νk,t|hk,Φt​[i]|.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑝𝑘subscriptΦ𝑡delimited-[]𝑖subscript𝜌𝑘subscript𝜈𝑘𝑡subscript𝑐𝑡delimited-[]𝑖subscriptℎ𝑘subscriptΦ𝑡delimited-[]𝑖formulae-sequencefor-all𝑘𝒦subscript𝑐𝑡delimited-[]𝑖1subscript𝑃1subscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝜌𝑘subscript𝜈𝑘𝑡subscriptℎ𝑘subscriptΦ𝑡delimited-[]𝑖p_{k,\Phi_{t}[i]}=\frac{\rho_{k}\nu_{k,t}}{c_{t}[i]h_{k,\Phi_{t}[i]}},\;\forall k\in\mathcal{K},c_{t}[i]=\frac{1}{\sqrt{P_{1}}}\max_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\frac{\rho_{k}\nu_{k,t}}{|h_{k,\Phi_{t}[i]}|}. (21)

Moreover, the minimum etsubscript𝑒𝑡e_{t} is given by

et=σ2P1​∑i=1dmaxk∈𝒦⁡ρk2​νk,t2|hk,Φt​[i]|2.subscript𝑒𝑡superscript𝜎2subscript𝑃1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑subscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝜌𝑘2superscriptsubscript𝜈𝑘𝑡2superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘subscriptΦ𝑡delimited-[]𝑖2e_{t}=\frac{\sigma^{2}}{P_{1}}\sum_{i=1}^{d}\max_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\frac{\rho_{k}^{2}\nu_{k,t}^{2}}{|h_{k,\Phi_{t}[i]}|^{2}}. (22)
Proof:

See Appendix A. ∎

Lemma III.1 gives the optimal solution to {pk,Φt​[i],ct​[i]}subscript𝑝𝑘subscriptΦ𝑡delimited-[]𝑖subscript𝑐𝑡delimited-[]𝑖\{p_{k,\Phi_{t}[i]},c_{t}[i]\} and the analytical expression of the minimum model aggregation error etsubscript𝑒𝑡e_{t} for given channel coefficients {hk,Φt​[i]}subscriptℎ𝑘subscriptΦ𝑡delimited-[]𝑖\{h_{k,\Phi_{t}[i]}\}. To facilitate the convergence analysis, we need a tractable expression for the model aggregation error etsubscript𝑒𝑡e_{t} that is independent of the instantaneous channel coefficients. Based on Lemma III.1 and Assumption 3, we obtain an upper bound of the expected value of etsubscript𝑒𝑡e_{t} in the following lemma.

Lemma III.2

With Assumption 3, we have

𝔼​[et]≤λt2​τ2​G2​σ2P1​𝔼​[maxk∈𝒦⁡ρk2|hk|2],𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑒𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑡2superscript𝜏2superscript𝐺2superscript𝜎2subscript𝑃1𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝜌𝑘2superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘2\mathbb{E}[e_{t}]\leq\lambda_{t}^{2}\frac{\tau^{2}G^{2}\sigma^{2}}{P_{1}}\mathbb{E}\left[\max_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\frac{\rho_{k}^{2}}{|h_{k}|^{2}}\right], (23)

where the expectations are taken with respect to the local mini-batch samples and the channel fading coefficients, and {hk,∀k∈𝒦}subscriptℎ𝑘for-all𝑘𝒦\{h_{k},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}\} are virtual i.i.d. random variables following the Gaussian distribution of 𝒞​𝒩​(0,1)𝒞𝒩01\mathcal{CN}(0,1).

Proof:

See Appendix B. ∎

III-B Convergence Result

With Lemma III.2 and Assumptions 1-3, we derive an upper bound of 𝔼​[F​(𝐰^T)−F∗]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript^𝐰𝑇superscript𝐹\mathbb{E}[F(\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{T})-F^{*}] in the following theorem.

Theorem III.1

Let the learning rate λt=8μ​τ​(γ+t)subscript𝜆𝑡8𝜇𝜏𝛾𝑡\lambda_{t}=\frac{8}{\mu\tau(\gamma+t)} and the corresponding weight of the t𝑡t-th global model ηt=(γ+t)2subscript𝜂𝑡superscript𝛾𝑡2\eta_{t}=(\gamma+t)^{2} with γ≥16​Lμ𝛾16𝐿𝜇\gamma\geq\frac{16L}{\mu}. With Assumptions 1-3, we have

𝔼[\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[ F(𝐰^T)−F∗]≤8​T​(T+2​γ)μ​ST(2​τ2+13​τG2+4​L​Γτ\displaystyle F(\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{T})-F^{*}]\leq\frac{8T(T+2\gamma)}{\mu S_{T}}\bigg{(}\frac{2\tau^{2}+1}{3\tau}G^{2}+\frac{4L\Gamma}{\tau}
+G2​σ2P1𝔼[maxk∈𝒦ρk2|hk|2])+μ​γ34​ST𝔼[∥𝐰0−𝐰∗∥22],\displaystyle+\frac{G^{2}\sigma^{2}}{P_{1}}\mathbb{E}\left[\max_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\frac{\rho_{k}^{2}}{|h_{k}|^{2}}\right]\bigg{)}+\frac{\mu\gamma^{3}}{4S_{T}}\mathbb{E}[\|\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\|_{2}^{2}], (24)

where STsubscript𝑆𝑇S_{T} is defined in (5), and the expectations are taken with respect to the local mini-batch samples, the communication noise, and the channel fading coefficients.

Proof:

See Appendix C. ∎

From Theorem III.1, we see that 𝔼​[F​(𝐰^T)−F∗]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript^𝐰𝑇superscript𝐹\mathbb{E}[F(\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{T})-F^{*}] has an upper bound related to the term 𝔼​[maxk∈𝒦⁡ρk2|hk|2]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝜌𝑘2superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘2\mathbb{E}\big{[}\max_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\frac{\rho_{k}^{2}}{|h_{k}|^{2}}\big{]}, which refers to the expected model aggregation error. Since the expected error is independent of the instantaneous channel coefficients {hk,Φt​[i]}subscriptℎ𝑘subscriptΦ𝑡delimited-[]𝑖\{h_{k,\Phi_{t}[i]}\}, the result in Theorem III.1 applies to any subcarrier allocation scheme. However, Theorem III.1 does not explicitly reveal the effect of τ𝜏\tau and T𝑇T. To this end, we further characterize the convergence behavior of 𝔼​[F​(𝐰^T)−F∗]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript^𝐰𝑇superscript𝐹\mathbb{E}[F(\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{T})-F^{*}] in the large-system limit, i.e., T→∞→𝑇T\rightarrow\infty, in the following corollary.

Corollary III.1

Suppose that the assumptions and conditions in Theorem III.1 hold. We have

𝔼​[F​(𝐰^T)−F∗]≤ζ​(τ)T+2​γ​ζ​(τ)T2+3​μ​γ3​𝔼​[‖𝐰0−𝐰∗‖22]4​T3,𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript^𝐰𝑇superscript𝐹𝜁𝜏𝑇2𝛾𝜁𝜏superscript𝑇23𝜇superscript𝛾3𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝐰0superscript𝐰224superscript𝑇3\mathbb{E}[F(\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{T})-F^{*}]\leq\frac{\zeta(\tau)}{T}+\frac{2\gamma\zeta(\tau)}{T^{2}}+\frac{3\mu\gamma^{3}\mathbb{E}[\|\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\|_{2}^{2}]}{4T^{3}}, (25)

where

ζ​(τ)≜24μ​(2​τ2+13​τ​G2+4​L​Γτ+G2​σ2P1​𝔼​[maxk∈𝒦⁡ρk2|hk|2]).≜𝜁𝜏24𝜇2superscript𝜏213𝜏superscript𝐺24𝐿Γ𝜏superscript𝐺2superscript𝜎2subscript𝑃1𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝜌𝑘2superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘2\zeta(\tau)\triangleq\frac{24}{\mu}\left(\frac{2\tau^{2}+1}{3\tau}G^{2}+\frac{4L\Gamma}{\tau}+\frac{G^{2}\sigma^{2}}{P_{1}}\mathbb{E}\left[\max_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\frac{\rho_{k}^{2}}{|h_{k}|^{2}}\right]\right). (26)

Moreover, when T𝑇T is sufficiently large, i.e., T→∞→𝑇T\rightarrow\infty, the last two terms on the right hand side (r.h.s.) of (25) are diminishing as 1T2,1T3→0→1superscript𝑇21superscript𝑇30\frac{1}{T^{2}},\frac{1}{T^{3}}\rightarrow 0. In this case, we can approximate the upper bound of 𝔼​[F​(𝐰^T)−F∗]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript^𝐰𝑇superscript𝐹\mathbb{E}[F(\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{T})-F^{*}] as

𝔼​[F​(𝐰^T)−F∗]≤ζ​(τ)T+O​(1T2)≈ζ​(τ)TasT→∞.formulae-sequence𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript^𝐰𝑇superscript𝐹𝜁𝜏𝑇𝑂1superscript𝑇2𝜁𝜏𝑇→as𝑇\mathbb{E}[F(\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{T})-F^{*}]\leq\frac{\zeta(\tau)}{T}+O\left(\frac{1}{T^{2}}\right)\approx\frac{\zeta(\tau)}{T}\quad\text{as}\quad T\rightarrow\infty. (27)
Proof:

ST=subscript𝑆𝑇absent\displaystyle S_{T}= ∑t=0T−1γ2+2​γ​t+t2superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1superscript𝛾22𝛾𝑡superscript𝑡2\displaystyle\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\gamma^{2}+2\gamma t+t^{2}
=\displaystyle= γ2​T+γ​T​(T−1)+T​(T−1)​(2​T−1)6superscript𝛾2𝑇𝛾𝑇𝑇1𝑇𝑇12𝑇16\displaystyle\gamma^{2}T+\gamma T(T-1)+\frac{T(T-1)(2T-1)}{6}
≥\displaystyle\geq 13​T3.13superscript𝑇3\displaystyle\frac{1}{3}T^{3}. (28)

Plugging this result into (III.1), we obtain (25). ∎

From Corollary III.1, we see that the output of the FL training process 𝐰^Tsubscript^𝐰𝑇\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{T} guarantees to converge to the global optimum and over-the-air FL has a convergence rate of O​(1T)𝑂1𝑇O(\frac{1}{T}) for a sufficiently large T𝑇T. Moreover, as shown in (27), the asymptotic upper bound in the large-system limit is a function of the learning hyper-parameters τ𝜏\tau and T𝑇T. Since T𝑇T is sufficiently large in practice, we use the upper bound in (27) as an approximation of 𝔼​[F​(𝐰^T)−F∗]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript^𝐰𝑇superscript𝐹\mathbb{E}[F(\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{T})-F^{*}], i.e., 𝔼​[F​(𝐰^T)−F∗]≈ζ​(τ)T𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript^𝐰𝑇superscript𝐹𝜁𝜏𝑇\mathbb{E}[F(\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{T})-F^{*}]\approx\frac{\zeta(\tau)}{T}, and asymptotically optimize τ𝜏\tau and T𝑇T in the next subsection.

III-C Optimization of Learning Parameters

To obtain an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-accurate solution, i.e., to achieve 𝔼​[F​(𝐰^T)−F∗]≤ϵ𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript^𝐰𝑇superscript𝐹italic-ϵ\mathbb{E}[F(\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{T})-F^{*}]\leq\epsilon, it is sufficient to ensure ζ​(τ)T≤ϵ𝜁𝜏𝑇italic-ϵ\frac{\zeta(\tau)}{T}\leq\epsilon, which yields

T≥𝑇absent\displaystyle T\geq ζ​(τ)ϵ𝜁𝜏italic-ϵ\displaystyle\frac{\zeta(\tau)}{\epsilon}
=\displaystyle= 24μ​ϵ​(2​G23​τ+G2+12​L​Γ3​τ+G2​σ2P1​𝔼​[maxk∈𝒦⁡ρk2|hk|2]).24𝜇italic-ϵ2superscript𝐺23𝜏superscript𝐺212𝐿Γ3𝜏superscript𝐺2superscript𝜎2subscript𝑃1𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝜌𝑘2superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘2\displaystyle\frac{24}{\mu\epsilon}\left(\frac{2G^{2}}{3}\tau+\frac{G^{2}+12L\Gamma}{3\tau}+\frac{G^{2}\sigma^{2}}{P_{1}}\mathbb{E}\left[\max_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\frac{\rho_{k}^{2}}{|h_{k}|^{2}}\right]\right). (29)

The last term on the r.h.s. of (III-C) reflects the effect of the over-the-air model aggregation: A smaller error in model aggregation (i.e., etsubscript𝑒𝑡e_{t}) leads to a smaller number of required training rounds T𝑇T. From (III-C), we see that T𝑇T is lower bounded by a function of τ𝜏\tau, which is not monotonic. Specifically, the r.h.s. of (III-C) first decreases and then increases with τ𝜏\tau, showing that the minimizer of ζ​(τ)𝜁𝜏\zeta(\tau) exists. Note that we can equivalently minimize the radio resource consumption of over-the-air FL by minimizing the required communication rounds T𝑇T. To obtain the minimum T∗superscript𝑇T^{*}, it suffices to find the optimal τ∗superscript𝜏\tau^{*} that minimizes ζ​(τ)𝜁𝜏\zeta(\tau), i.e., τ∗=arg⁡minζ​(τ)superscript𝜏𝜁𝜏\tau^{*}=\mathop{\arg\min}\zeta(\tau), which is equivalent to solving the following optimization problem:

minτsubscript𝜏\displaystyle\min_{\tau}\quad ψ​(τ)=2​G23​τ+G2+12​L​Γ3​τ𝜓𝜏2superscript𝐺23𝜏superscript𝐺212𝐿Γ3𝜏\displaystyle\psi(\tau)=\frac{2G^{2}}{3}\tau+\frac{G^{2}+12L\Gamma}{3\tau} (30a)
s.t.formulae-sequencest\displaystyle{\rm s.t.}~{}~{}~{} τ∈ℤ+,τ≥1,formulae-sequence𝜏superscriptℤ𝜏1\displaystyle\tau\in\mathbb{Z}^{+},\tau\geq 1, (30b)

where the objective function ψ​(τ)𝜓𝜏\psi(\tau) is derived from ζ​(τ)𝜁𝜏\zeta(\tau) by omitting the constant term.

Problem (30) is an one-dimensional integer programming problem and can be solved optimally as follows. Specifically, we first solve the following relaxed problem:

minτ∈ℝ,τ≥1ψ​(τ)=2​G23​τ+G2+12​L​Γ3​τ.subscriptformulae-sequence𝜏ℝ𝜏1𝜓𝜏2superscript𝐺23𝜏superscript𝐺212𝐿Γ3𝜏\min_{\tau\in\mathbb{R},\tau\geq 1}\quad\psi(\tau)=\frac{2G^{2}}{3}\tau+\frac{G^{2}+12L\Gamma}{3\tau}. (31)

Since Problem (31) is convex, the optimal solution is given by

τrelax=max⁡{1,12+6​L​ΓG2}.subscript𝜏relax1126𝐿Γsuperscript𝐺2\tau_{\textrm{relax}}=\max\left\{1,\sqrt{\frac{1}{2}+\frac{6L\Gamma}{G^{2}}}\right\}. (32)

Then, the optimal solution τ∗superscript𝜏\tau^{*} to Problem (30) can be obtained by simply rounding (32) as

τ∗=argminτ∈{⌊τrelax⌋,⌈τrelax⌉}ψ​(τ),superscript𝜏subscriptargmin𝜏subscript𝜏relaxsubscript𝜏relax𝜓𝜏\tau^{*}=\operatorname*{argmin}_{\tau\in\{\lfloor\tau_{\textrm{relax}}\rfloor,\lceil\tau_{\textrm{relax}}\rceil\}}\psi(\tau), (33)

where ⌊⋅⌋⋅\lfloor\cdot\rfloor denotes the floor function, and ⌈⋅⌉⋅\lceil\cdot\rceil denotes the ceiling function.

Substituting the optimal value of τ∗superscript𝜏\tau^{*} in (33) into (III-C), we have

T≥𝑇absent\displaystyle T\geq ζ​(τ∗)ϵ𝜁superscript𝜏italic-ϵ\displaystyle\frac{\zeta(\tau^{*})}{\epsilon}
=\displaystyle= 24μ​ϵ​(2​G23​τ∗+G2+12​L​Γ3​τ∗+G2​σ2P1​𝔼​[maxk∈𝒦⁡ρk2|hk|2]).24𝜇italic-ϵ2superscript𝐺23superscript𝜏superscript𝐺212𝐿Γ3superscript𝜏superscript𝐺2superscript𝜎2subscript𝑃1𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝜌𝑘2superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘2\displaystyle\frac{24}{\mu\epsilon}\left(\frac{2G^{2}}{3}\tau^{*}+\frac{G^{2}+12L\Gamma}{3\tau^{*}}+\frac{G^{2}\sigma^{2}}{P_{1}}\mathbb{E}\left[\max_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\frac{\rho_{k}^{2}}{|h_{k}|^{2}}\right]\right). (34)

As T∈ℤ+𝑇superscriptℤT\in\mathbb{Z}^{+}, the minimum T∗superscript𝑇T^{*} satisfying (III-C) is given by

T∗=⌈24μ​ϵ​(2​G23​τ∗+G2+12​L​Γ3​τ∗+G2​σ2P1​𝔼​[maxk∈𝒦⁡ρk2|hk|2])⌉.superscript𝑇24𝜇italic-ϵ2superscript𝐺23superscript𝜏superscript𝐺212𝐿Γ3superscript𝜏superscript𝐺2superscript𝜎2subscript𝑃1𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝜌𝑘2superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘2T^{*}\!=\!\left\lceil\!\frac{24}{\mu\epsilon}\left(\!\frac{2G^{2}}{3}\tau^{*}+\frac{G^{2}+12L\Gamma}{3\tau^{*}}+\frac{G^{2}\sigma^{2}}{P_{1}}\mathbb{E}\left[\max_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\frac{\rho_{k}^{2}}{|h_{k}|^{2}}\right]\!\right)\!\right\rceil. (35)

We see from (32) and (35) that the large-system asymptotic results τ∗superscript𝜏\tau^{*} and T∗superscript𝑇T^{*} depend on the parameters L,Γ𝐿ΓL,\Gamma, and G𝐺G, which are determined by the data distribution and the learning task. The accuracy of the derived {τ∗,T∗}superscript𝜏superscript𝑇\{\tau^{*},T^{*}\} is verified by numerical results in Section V.

IV Online Subcarrier Allocation for CFLIT

We have discussed the optimization of {T,τ,pk,Φt​[i],ct​[i]}𝑇𝜏subscript𝑝𝑘subscriptΦ𝑡delimited-[]𝑖subscript𝑐𝑡delimited-[]𝑖\{T,\tau,p_{k,\Phi_{t}[i]},c_{t}[i]\} in Section III. The remaining challenge of solving Problem (P1) lies in optimizing the binary subcarrier allocation variables {bn,m,s,om,s}subscript𝑏𝑛𝑚𝑠subscript𝑜𝑚𝑠\{b_{n,m,s},o_{m,s}\} without the non-causal CSI. In this section, we propose a low-complexity threshold-based online algorithm that only requires the CSI in the current symbol duration s𝑠s to optimize {bn,m,s,om,s}subscript𝑏𝑛𝑚𝑠subscript𝑜𝑚𝑠\{b_{n,m,s},o_{m,s}\} in an online manner. Furthermore, we analyze the achievable performance of the proposed algorithm.

IV-A Threshold-Based Online Subcarrier Allocation

As discussed in Section III, our analysis of FL convergence does not rely on the instantaneous CSI of FL devices. Moreover, the channel coefficients of FL devices are independent of those of IT devices. Therefore, the convergence analysis in Section III is applicable to arbitrary subcarrier allocation. With the optimized {T,τ,pk,Φt​[i],ct​[i]}𝑇𝜏subscript𝑝𝑘subscriptΦ𝑡delimited-[]𝑖subscript𝑐𝑡delimited-[]𝑖\{T,\tau,p_{k,\Phi_{t}[i]},c_{t}[i]\}, the FL convergence requirement in (15b) can be satisfied by ensuring that the number of allocated subcarriers for over-the-air FL is sufficiently large to complete T∗superscript𝑇T^{*} rounds of model aggregation. Accordingly, Problem (P1) is simplified as:

(P2):​max{bn,m,s,om,s}(P2):subscriptsubscript𝑏𝑛𝑚𝑠subscript𝑜𝑚𝑠\displaystyle\text{(P2):}\max_{\{b_{n,m,s},o_{m,s}\}}~{} Ravgsubscript𝑅avg\displaystyle R_{\text{avg}} (36a)
s.t.formulae-sequencest\displaystyle{\rm s.t.}\qquad ∑s=1S∑m=1Mom,s≥d​T∗,superscriptsubscript𝑠1𝑆superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝑜𝑚𝑠𝑑superscript𝑇\displaystyle\sum_{s=1}^{S}\sum_{m=1}^{M}o_{m,s}\geq dT^{*}, (36b)
∑n=1Nbn,m,s+om,s≤1,∀m,s,superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝑏𝑛𝑚𝑠subscript𝑜𝑚𝑠1for-all𝑚𝑠\displaystyle\sum_{n=1}^{N}b_{n,m,s}+o_{m,s}\leq 1,\forall m,s, (36c)
bn,m,s∈{0,1},∀n,m,s,subscript𝑏𝑛𝑚𝑠01for-all𝑛𝑚𝑠\displaystyle b_{n,m,s}\in\{0,1\},\forall n,m,s, (36d)
om,s∈{0,1},∀m,s.subscript𝑜𝑚𝑠01for-all𝑚𝑠\displaystyle o_{m,s}\in\{0,1\},\forall m,s. (36e)

We note that the subcarrier allocation is independent of the channel coefficients of FL devices {hk,m,s}subscriptℎ𝑘𝑚𝑠\{h_{k,m,s}\}, as implied by (36a) and (36b). When the CSI of the entire time horizon is available, a simple offline solution to (P2) follows. Denote the highest channel gain among all the IT devices on the m𝑚m-th subcarrier of the s𝑠s-th OFDM symbol by g¯m,ssubscript¯𝑔𝑚𝑠\bar{g}_{m,s} as

g¯m,s=maxn∈𝒩⁡{|g1,m,s|2,⋯,|gn,m,s|2,⋯,|gN,m,s|2}.subscript¯𝑔𝑚𝑠subscript𝑛𝒩superscriptsubscript𝑔1𝑚𝑠2⋯superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑛𝑚𝑠2⋯superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑁𝑚𝑠2\bar{g}_{m,s}=\max_{n\in\mathcal{N}}\left\{|g_{1,m,s}|^{2},\cdots,|g_{n,m,s}|^{2},\cdots,|g_{N,m,s}|^{2}\right\}. (37)

The optimal subcarrier allocation decision {bn,m,s,om,s}subscript𝑏𝑛𝑚𝑠subscript𝑜𝑚𝑠\{b_{n,m,s},o_{m,s}\} is given by sorting M​S𝑀𝑆MS channel gains g¯m,ssubscript¯𝑔𝑚𝑠\bar{g}_{m,s} in the descending order and assigning the top M​S−d​T∗𝑀𝑆𝑑superscript𝑇MS-dT^{*} subcarriers to IT and the last d​T∗𝑑superscript𝑇dT^{*} to over-the-air FL. Meanwhile, for any om,s=0subscript𝑜𝑚𝑠0o_{m,s}=0, the subcarrier is assigned to the IT device with the highest channel gain. In practice, however, such CSI is unavailable in advance. This makes it difficult to exactly find these globally best subcarriers in each symbol duration. In the following, we propose a threshold-based online subcarrier allocation algorithm that only requires the current CSI to mimic the offline optimal solution.

Since the channel coefficient gn,m,ssubscript𝑔𝑛𝑚𝑠g_{n,m,s} follows the i.i.d. complex Gaussian distribution of 𝒞​𝒩​(0,1)𝒞𝒩01\mathcal{CN}(0,1), the channel gain |gn,m,s|2,∀n,m,s,superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑛𝑚𝑠2for-all𝑛𝑚𝑠|g_{n,m,s}|^{2},\forall n,m,s, follows the i.i.d. chi-squared distribution with 2 degrees of freedom, i.e., |gn,m,s|2∼χ2​(2)similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝑛𝑚𝑠2superscript𝜒22|g_{n,m,s}|^{2}\sim\chi^{2}(2), whose cumulative distribution function (CDF) is specified by

F|gn,m,s|2​(x)=P​(|gn,m,s|2≤x)=1−e−x.subscript𝐹superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑛𝑚𝑠2𝑥𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑛𝑚𝑠2𝑥1superscript𝑒𝑥\displaystyle F_{|g_{n,m,s}|^{2}}(x)=P(|g_{n,m,s}|^{2}\leq x)=1-e^{-x}. (38)

With (38), the CDF of g¯m,ssubscript¯𝑔𝑚𝑠\bar{g}_{m,s} is

Fg¯m,s​(x)=P​(g¯m,s≤x)=∏n=1NF|gn,m,s|2​(x)=(1−e−x)N.subscript𝐹subscript¯𝑔𝑚𝑠𝑥𝑃subscript¯𝑔𝑚𝑠𝑥superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑛1𝑁subscript𝐹superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑛𝑚𝑠2𝑥superscript1superscript𝑒𝑥𝑁F_{\bar{g}_{m,s}}(x)=P(\bar{g}_{m,s}\leq x)=\prod_{n=1}^{N}F_{|g_{n,m,s}|^{2}}(x)=(1-e^{-x})^{N}. (39)

Furthermore, the probability density function (PDF) of g¯m,ssubscript¯𝑔𝑚𝑠\bar{g}_{m,s} can be calculated as

fg¯m,s​(x)=subscript𝑓subscript¯𝑔𝑚𝑠𝑥absent\displaystyle f_{\bar{g}_{m,s}}(x)= d​Fg¯m,s​(x)d​x𝑑subscript𝐹subscript¯𝑔𝑚𝑠𝑥𝑑𝑥\displaystyle\frac{dF_{\bar{g}_{m,s}}(x)}{dx}
=\displaystyle= {N​e−x​(1−e−x)N−1,x≥0,0,otherwise.cases𝑁superscript𝑒𝑥superscript1superscript𝑒𝑥𝑁1𝑥00otherwise.\displaystyle\left\{\begin{array}[]{lc}Ne^{-x}(1-e^{-x})^{N-1},&\mbox{$x\geq 0$},\\ 0,&\mbox{otherwise.}\end{array}\right. (42)

Let pITsubscript𝑝ITp_{\text{IT}} denote the proportion of subcarriers allocated to IT devices in the entire time horizon. According to the offline optimal solution, we have

pIT=M​S−d​T∗M​S.subscript𝑝IT𝑀𝑆𝑑superscript𝑇𝑀𝑆p_{\text{IT}}=\frac{MS-dT^{*}}{MS}. (43)

To mimic the offline optimal subcarrier allocation, we can derive a threshold of {g¯m,s}subscript¯𝑔𝑚𝑠\{\bar{g}_{m,s}\}, denoted by q𝑞q, such that the expected proportion of subcarriers allocated to IT is pITsubscript𝑝ITp_{\text{IT}}. Specifically, a subcarrier is allocated to IT if the corresponding g¯m,ssubscript¯𝑔𝑚𝑠\bar{g}_{m,s} exceeds the threshold q𝑞q and allocated to over-the-air model aggregation otherwise. To this end, we employ the quantile function of g¯m,ssubscript¯𝑔𝑚𝑠\bar{g}_{m,s} to compute q𝑞q as

q=Qg¯m,s​(1−pIT)=𝑞subscript𝑄subscript¯𝑔𝑚𝑠1subscript𝑝ITabsent\displaystyle q=Q_{\bar{g}_{m,s}}(1-p_{\text{IT}})= inf{x∈ℝ:1−pIT≤Fg¯m,s​(x)}infimumconditional-set𝑥ℝ1subscript𝑝ITsubscript𝐹subscript¯𝑔𝑚𝑠𝑥\displaystyle\inf\{x\in\mathbb{R}:1-p_{\text{IT}}\leq F_{\bar{g}_{m,s}}(x)\}
=\displaystyle= −ln⁡(1−1−pITN).1𝑁1subscript𝑝IT\displaystyle-\ln\left(1-\sqrt[N]{1-p_{\text{IT}}}\right). (44)

Then, the online subcarrier allocation solution to (P2) is given by

om,s={1,g¯m,s<q,0,otherwise,subscript𝑜𝑚𝑠cases1subscript¯𝑔𝑚𝑠𝑞0otherwise,o_{m,s}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{lc}1,&\mbox{$\bar{g}_{m,s}<q$},\\ 0,&\mbox{otherwise,}\end{array}\right. (45)

and

bn,m,s={1,​​​​​ g¯m,s≥q and n=argmaxn′∈𝒩|gn′,m,s|2,0, otherwise.subscript𝑏𝑛𝑚𝑠cases1​​​​​ g¯m,s≥q and n=argmaxn′∈𝒩|gn′,m,s|20 otherwise.b_{n,m,s}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{lc}1,&\mbox{\!\!\!\!\! $\bar{g}_{m,s}\geq q$ and $n=\operatorname*{argmax}\limits_{n^{\prime}\in\mathcal{N}}|g_{n^{\prime},m,s}|^{2}$},\\ 0,&\mbox{ otherwise.}\end{array}\right. (46)

We summarize the proposed threshold-based online subcarrier allocation algorithm in Algorithm 1. We initialize om,s=1subscript𝑜𝑚𝑠1o_{m,s}=1, bn,m,s=0,∀nsubscript𝑏𝑛𝑚𝑠0for-all𝑛b_{n,m,s}=0,\forall n for all subcarriers and introduce an auxiliary variable Itotalsubscript𝐼totalI_{\textrm{total}} to denote the accumulated number of subcarriers allocated to IT. If the number of allocated subcarriers for FL achieves its maximum value d​T∗𝑑superscript𝑇dT^{*}, the remaining RBs will be allocated to IT; see Lines 7-8. By doing this, the proposed algorithm allocates exactly d​T∗𝑑superscript𝑇dT^{*} subcarriers to over-the-air FL, guaranteeing that the solution is always feasible to Problem (P2). Since the complexity of Lines 6-12 is O​(N)𝑂𝑁O(N), the computational complexity of allocating each subcarrier is O​(N)𝑂𝑁O(N). Therefore, the overall complexity of Algorithm 1 is O​(M​S​N)𝑂𝑀𝑆𝑁O(MSN).

g^m,s={g¯m,s,g¯m,s≥q,0,otherwise.subscript^𝑔𝑚𝑠casessubscript¯𝑔𝑚𝑠subscript¯𝑔𝑚𝑠𝑞0otherwise.\hat{g}_{m,s}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{lc}\bar{g}_{m,s},&\mbox{$\bar{g}_{m,s}\geq q$},\\ 0,&\mbox{otherwise.}\end{array}\right. (47)

V Numerical Results

In this section, we conduct experiments to verify our theoretical analysis and evaluate the performance of the proposed design.

V-A Experiment Settings

We simulate a single-cell model edge network that comprises one AP, K=20𝐾20K=20 FL devices, and N=5𝑁5N=5 IT devices with M=512𝑀512M=512 OFDM subcarriers. The frequency-selective channel has an exponential power delay profile with a delay spread of 666 taps. Unless otherwise stated, we set S=2000𝑆2000S=2000 with each symbol duration equals to 161616 μ​s𝜇𝑠\mu s, P1=P2=P=1subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2𝑃1P_{1}=P_{2}=P=1 W, ϕ=6italic-ϕ6\phi=6 dB, and σ2=0.1superscript𝜎20.1\sigma^{2}=0.1 W.

For over-the-air FL, we consider the regularized logistic regression task with the synthetic dataset specified in [27, Section 5]. Specifically, we generate the local data samples of each device k𝑘k {𝐗k,𝐲k}subscript𝐗𝑘subscript𝐲𝑘\{\mathbf{X}_{k},\mathbf{y}_{k}\} of size Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} according to the model yk,i=argmax(softmax​(𝐖k​𝐱k,i+𝐛k))subscript𝑦𝑘𝑖argmaxsoftmaxsubscript𝐖𝑘subscript𝐱𝑘𝑖subscript𝐛𝑘y_{k,i}=\operatorname*{argmax}(\text{softmax}(\mathbf{W}_{k}\mathbf{x}_{k,i}+\mathbf{b}_{k})), where softmax​(zi)≜ezi∑jezj≜softmaxsubscript𝑧𝑖superscript𝑒subscript𝑧𝑖subscript𝑗superscript𝑒subscript𝑧𝑗\text{softmax}(z_{i})\triangleq\frac{e^{z_{i}}}{\sum_{j}e^{z_{j}}} is the softmax function, 𝐗k∈ℝDk×60subscript𝐗𝑘superscriptℝsubscript𝐷𝑘60\mathbf{X}_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{D_{k}\times 60}, 𝐲k∈ℝDk×1subscript𝐲𝑘superscriptℝsubscript𝐷𝑘1\mathbf{y}_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{D_{k}\times 1}, 𝐖k∈ℝ10×60subscript𝐖𝑘superscriptℝ1060\mathbf{W}_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{10\times 60}, 𝐱k,i∈ℝ60×1subscript𝐱𝑘𝑖superscriptℝ601\mathbf{x}_{k,i}\in\mathbb{R}^{60\times 1}, and 𝐛k∈ℝ10×1subscript𝐛𝑘superscriptℝ101\mathbf{b}_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{10\times 1}. We draw each entry of 𝐖ksubscript𝐖𝑘\mathbf{W}_{k} and 𝐛ksubscript𝐛𝑘\mathbf{b}_{k} following the distribution of 𝒩​(uk,1)𝒩subscript𝑢𝑘1\mathcal{N}(u_{k},1) with uk∼𝒩​(0,α)similar-tosubscript𝑢𝑘𝒩0𝛼u_{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\alpha), and (𝐱k,i)jsubscriptsubscript𝐱𝑘𝑖𝑗(\mathbf{x}_{k,i})_{j} following the distribution of 𝒩​(vk,1j1.2)𝒩subscript𝑣𝑘1superscript𝑗1.2\mathcal{N}(v_{k},\frac{1}{j^{1.2}}) with vk∼𝒩​(Bk,1)similar-tosubscript𝑣𝑘𝒩subscript𝐵𝑘1v_{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(B_{k},1) and Bk∼𝒩​(0,β)similar-tosubscript𝐵𝑘𝒩0𝛽B_{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\beta). The loss function is given by

To minimize (53), all the FL devices train a common regression model consisting of an input layer and a softmax output layer with the total number of model parameters d𝑑d equals to 610610610. All the simulation results in this section are averaged over 202020 Monte Carlo trials.

V-B Verification of Learning Analysis

We first evaluate the optimality of the learning hyper-parameters τ∗superscript𝜏\tau^{*} and T∗superscript𝑇T^{*} derived in Section III. In Fig. 2, we plot the optimality gap of over-the-air FL, i.e., F​(𝐰^T)−F∗𝐹subscript^𝐰𝑇superscript𝐹F(\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{T})-F^{*}, with different values of τ𝜏\tau in 1,50015001,500 communication rounds. Our analysis in (33) shows that the optimal τ∗=6superscript𝜏6\tau^{*}=6, which corresponds to the best learning performance in Fig. 2. We see that τ=1𝜏1\tau=1 leads to a slower convergence rate and a higher final training loss than τ=6𝜏6\tau=6. On the other hand, due to the data heterogeneity, we observe evident performance degradation when τ>6𝜏6\tau>6 as too intensive local updating hurts the global convergence. With τ=6𝜏6\tau=6, it requires T=1293𝑇1293T=1293 rounds to achieve a 0.340.340.34-accurate solution, which matches our analytical result T∗=1208superscript𝑇1208T^{*}=1208 in (35).

In Fig. 3, we study the impact of the number of local updates on the required FL communication rounds T𝑇T to achieve a 0.360.360.36-accurate solution, i.e., F​(𝐰^T)−F∗≤0.36𝐹subscript^𝐰𝑇superscript𝐹0.36F(\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{T})-F^{*}\leq 0.36. We see from Fig. 3 that the value of T𝑇T is sensitive to the choice of τ𝜏\tau and their relationship is non-monotonic. This observation coincides with our analysis in Section III. Moreover, the optimal value of τ𝜏\tau obtained by the simulation (τ∗=5superscript𝜏5\tau^{*}=5) is close to our analysis (τ∗=6superscript𝜏6\tau^{*}=6), which verifies the accuracy of our theoretical learning optimization results in Section III.

V-C Simulations on CFLIT Performance

We compare the proposed CFLIT design with four baseline schemes. First, we consider the offline optimal subcarrier allocation scheme described in Section IV-A, where we assume that the non-causal CSI is available beforehand. This ideal baseline characterizes the best IT performance. Second, we consider the RSCA scheme described in Section IV-B, which randomly allocates each RB to IT with probability pITsubscript𝑝ITp_{\text{IT}} and to over-the-air FL with probability 1−pIT1subscript𝑝IT1-p_{\text{IT}}. Then, we consider two FL schemes with fixed learning configuration τ=1𝜏1\tau=1 and τ=10𝜏10\tau=10, where the corresponding subcarrier allocation is optimized by using Algorithm 1. For fair comparison, the numbers of local updates in the proposed scheme and RSCA are both optimized by (33) as τ∗=6superscript𝜏6\tau^{*}=6. For over-the-air FL, the number of communication rounds is determined offline by (35) with the learning target given by F​(𝐰^T)−F∗≤ϵ=0.36𝐹subscript^𝐰𝑇superscript𝐹italic-ϵ0.36F(\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{T})-F^{*}\leq\epsilon=0.36.

In Table I and Fig. 4, we present the average IT sum-rate and the FL loss, respectively, with S=2000𝑆2000S=2000 OFDM symbols. We observe that the proposed online algorithm achieves a comparable average IT sum-rate with the offline scheme. Moreover, the proposed scheme outperforms all the other baselines in terms of both the FL convergence and the IT data rate. Although the optimality gap of the baseline with τ=1𝜏1\tau=1 gradually approaches that of the proposed scheme, it fails to serve the IT devices as all the radio resources are used for over-the-air model aggregation. Due to the data heterogeneity, the baseline with τ=10𝜏10\tau=10 tends to converge to local optima and requires more FL communication rounds than the proposed scheme, which leads to a worse CFLIT system performance. Thanks to the optimization of τ𝜏\tau, the RSCA scheme achieves comparable learning performance with the proposed scheme, but it achieves a lower IT data rate than our proposed method. By joint communication and learning design, the proposed scheme efficiently utilizes the limited radio resources and thus provides better performance for the coexistence of over-the-air FL and IT.

In Fig. 5, we study the impact of the number of IT devices N𝑁N on the average IT sum-rate with S=2000𝑆2000S=2000 OFDM symbols. We see that the proposed scheme achieves a similar average IT sum-rate to the offline scheme and outperforms the other baselines. As N𝑁N increases, the performance gap between the RSCA scheme and the proposed scheme becomes smaller. This is because increasing the number of IT devices improves the effective received signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) for all the schemes. In contrast, the two baselines with fixed FL design, i.e., τ=1𝜏1\tau=1 and τ=10𝜏10\tau=10, suffer from a slow FL convergence rate. Consequently, they have much less remaining RBs for uplink IT compared with the proposed scheme.

In Figs. 6 and 7, we study the impact of the number of OFDM symbols S𝑆S on the FL performance and the average IT sum-rate, respectively. We see that the value of S𝑆S reflects the availability of radio resources and thus critically affects the performance of both the FL and the IT. Specifically, when S𝑆S is small, e.g., S≤2000𝑆2000S\leq 2000, the radio resources should be allocated to over-the-air FL to fulfill the convergence requirement, which limits the data rate of IT devices. As S𝑆S increases, more RBs can be used for uplink data transmissions, leading to a higher IT data rate. As shown in Fig. 7, the proposed online algorithm achieves near-optimal IT performance. With efficient exploitation of the learning properties, our proposed design well balances the resource allocation in FL and IT and thus achieves a better performance compared with the other baselines. The above observation verifies the superiority of the proposed design in supporting the coexistence of FL and IT, especially when radio resources are limited.

Next, we investigate the effect of the SNR, defined as the ratio of the transmit power P𝑃P to the noise power σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}. Figs. 8 and 9 show that FL and IT exhibit distinct sensitivities to communication errors. Although a higher SNR leads to a larger IT data rate, its impact on FL performance is not consistently monotonic. For example, when the SNR decreases from 30 dB to 10 dB, the training performance is not affected because the model aggregation error is small enough to preserve convergence. However, when the SNR falls below 10 dB, the substantial communication errors cause significant perturbations to the gradient directions, resulting in a larger training loss.

V-D CFLIT Performance with Model Compression

Finally, we show the feasibility of fusing the proposed method with model sparsification/compression. We simulate the proposed design with the existing model compression scheme in [23]. Specifically, before uploading the local change vector, each FL device first sparsifies it to an s𝑠s-sparse vector and then projects the sparsified vector to the d′superscript𝑑′d^{\prime}-dimensional subspace using an i.i.d. Gaussian projection matrix 𝐀∈ℝd′×d𝐀superscriptℝsuperscript𝑑′𝑑\mathbf{A}\in\mathbb{R}^{d^{\prime}\times d}, with s≤d′<d𝑠superscript𝑑′𝑑s\leq d^{\prime}<d. The model compression ratio is given by υ≜d′/d∈(0,1]≜𝜐superscript𝑑′𝑑01\upsilon\triangleq d^{\prime}/d\in(0,1]. Accordingly, the number of RBs for over-the-air model aggregation is changed from d​T∗𝑑superscript𝑇dT^{*} to υ​d​T∗𝜐𝑑superscript𝑇\upsilon dT^{*}. Therefore, υ𝜐\upsilon reflects the communication-compression tradeoff: A smaller υ𝜐\upsilon means more compressed and thus less accurate model aggregation but less radio resource consumption. Table II and Fig. 10 show the average IT sum-rate and the FL training loss versus the value of υ𝜐\upsilon. The simulation parameters can be found in Fig. 4. Decreasing υ𝜐\upsilon results in lower radio resource consumption during FL, which in turn increases the IT data rate. However, compressing the gradient vectors introduces additional errors to model aggregation and impairs the training performance. Particularly, when υ𝜐\upsilon is 0.1, the compression error is significantly large, leading to a large training loss. The result demonstrates that the proposed design can be readily extended to the system with model sparsification/compression.

VI Conclusions

In this paper, we proposed a novel CFLIT framework to support the coexistence of over-the-air FL and uplink information transfer. To maximize the average IT data rate while ensuring the convergence of over-the-air FL, we studied the joint optimization of the OFDM subcarrier allocation, the transceiver design, and the FL hyper-parameters. We analyzed the convergence of over-the-air FL to minimize the bandwidth consumption needed for FL convergence guarantee. Based on the analysis, we optimized the transceiver design, the number of local updates, and the number of FL communication rounds. Moreover, we proposed a low-complexity online algorithm to optimize the CFLIT subcarrier allocation under the time-varying channels and derived a closed-form expression of its achievable IT data rate. Extensive simulations verify our analysis and demonstrate the performance improvement, in both the FL convergence and the average IT data rate, of the proposed design compared with the baselines.

Finally, we conclude the paper with some interesting future directions. First, we assumed perfect synchronization of the local model updates transmitted from FL devices for over-the-air model aggregation, which is difficult to achieve in practice. The lack of synchronization will result in not only signal misalignment but also inter-symbol interference. Therefore, new designs on pre-equalization and de-noising are needed to address the synchronization issue in the coexisting system. Second, we showed numerically in Section V-D that combining our design with separate model compression can reduce the communication cost of FL. Joint optimization of the model aggregation frequency and model compression/quantization under a unified framework would further improve the communication efficiency in over-the-air FL. Moreover, device selection and scheduling are also key designing factors that significantly affect the FL convergence. Further investigation is necessary to fully understand their impacts on the performance of the coexisting system.
